facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2177 of 1966 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 12, 1963 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1076 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2177 of1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 12, 1963 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1076 of 1962.

facts.text: Respondents, a Hindu undivided family, were assessed for assessment year 1949-50 to tax under s 23 of the Mysore Income-tax Act on total income of Rs. 10,100/-

anchor.surface_text: The respondents-a Hindu undivided family-were assessed for the assessment year 1949-50 to tax under s 23 of the Mysore Income-tax Act on a total income of Rs. 10,100/-

facts.text: Second Additional Income-tax Officer Urban Circle, Bangalore, commenced proceeding under s. 34 of Mysore Income-tax Act for re-assessment for 1949-50 and served notice on March 6, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Second Additional Income-tax Officer  Urban Circle , Bangalore, companymenced a proceeding under s. 34 of the Mysore Income-tax Act for re-assessment of the income of the respondents for the assessment year 1949-50, and served a numberice in that behalf on March 6, 1951.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer determined respondents' total income at Rs. 75,957/- on May 21, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On May 21, 1954 the Income-tax Officer determined the respondents total income at Rs. 75,957/-.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax A Range, Bangalore, by order dated November 4, 1961, set aside the order and directed Income-tax Officer to make fresh assessment after inquiries.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal against the order, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax. A Range, Bangalore, by order dated November 4, 1961, set aside the order and directed the Income-tax Officer to make a fresh assessment after making inquiries on certain matters specified in the order.

facts.text: Respondents requested reference under s. 66(2) of Mysore Income-tax Act, Commissioner referred two questions to High Court of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: At the request of the respondents under s. 66 2  of the Mysore Income-tax Act, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Mysore, referred the following questions to the High Court of Mysore

facts.text: High Court answered the second question in the affirmative; respondents did not press the first question.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the reference, the respondents did number press the first question, and the High Court answered the second question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer commenced inquiry directed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer companymenced inquiry directed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Respondents applied to High Court of Mysore for writ of prohibition restraining Income-tax Officer from continuing assessment for 1949-50 on ground of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-, then applied to the High Court of Mysore for issue of a writ of prohibition restraining the Income-tax Officer from companytinuing the assessment proceeding for the year 1949-50 on the plea that the proceeding was because of expiry of the period of limitation barred.

facts.text: High Court of Mysore upheld respondents' contention and allowed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Mysore upheld the companytention of the respondents and allowed the petition.

facts.text: High Court held proceedings barred by limitation analogous to Mysore Sales Tax Act rule in K.S. Subbarayappa case.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the High Court the provisions of s. 34 of the Mysore Income-tax Act were more or less similar to Rule 34 of the Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1948. Hence the present case clearly companyes within the rule laid down by this Court in M s K. S. Subbarayappa and Sons v. State of Mysore  1952  Mysore L. J. 2341 which means that the present proceedings are barred.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court with special leave.

facts.text: Notice under s.34 served on March 6, 1951 within four years of end of assessment year 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice for re-assessment was in fact served on the respon- dents on March 6, 1951 under s. 34 of the Mysore Act. That numberice was served within four years of the end of the year of assessment 1949-50,

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner vacated order of May 21, 1954 but did not set aside the notice; remanded for further inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner vacated the order of assessment dated May 21, 1954, but he did number set aside the numberice served upon the respondents. He merely remanded the case for further inquiry to be made in the light of the directions given by him.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that re-assessment proceeding commenced with notice of March 1951 was not barred.

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to appreciate the grounds on which it companyld be held that the proceeding for re-assessment to tax the income which had escaped assessment in the year 1949-50 companymenced after due numberice served on March 1951 was barred. The High Court was, in our judgment, plainly in error in holding that the proceeding for re- assessment was barred.

facts.text: First reference question not pressed before High Court and deemed answered against respondents.

anchor.surface_text: It must also be remembered that the respondents had under an order of the Commissioner obtained a reference on the first question set out hereinbefore. That question was number pressed before the High Court, and it must be deemed to have been answered against the respondents.

facts.text: Proceeding for assessment year 1949-50 governed by Mysore Income-tax Act even after merger with Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: Even after the merger of the State of Mysore with the Union of India a proceeding for assessment of income-tax relating to the assessment year 1949-50 has to be heard and disposed of under the Mysore Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed.

facts.text: Second question referred: whether Appellate Assistant Commissioner competent to set aside and direct re-assessment.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts and in the circumstances of the assessees case whether within the meaning of s. 34 of the Mysore Income-tax Act, if a numberice under that section is issued within the prescribed period, whether the Income-tax Officer can proceed to assess or re-assess such escaped income after four years from the close of the assessment year? On the facts and in the circumstances of the case, whether the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Incometax is companypetent to set aside and give directions to the Income-tax Officer to re-do the assessment in the manner the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax has done?

facts.text: Income-tax Officer was of the view that profits or gains had escaped assessment in 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: and the Income-tax Officer was of the view that tie profits or gains chargeable to income-tax had escaped assessment in the year 1949-50.
Appeal by special leave from
special leave.

anchor.surface_text: on the plea that the proceeding was because of expiry of the period of limitation barred. The High Court of Mysore upheld the contention of the respondents and allowed the petition.

issues.text: whether the respondents could reagitate the first question in a petition for the issue of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: That question could number thereafter be reagitated by the respondents in a petition for the issue of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The appeal is allowed.

arguments.claim: The re-assessment proceeding for 1949-50 is barred by expiry of the period of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-, then applied to the High Court of Mysore for issue of a writ of prohibition restraining the Income-tax Officer from companytinuing the assessment proceeding for the year 1949-50 on the plea that the proceeding was because of expiry of the period of limitation barred.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ay 21, 1954, but he did number set aside the numberice served upon the respondents. He merely remanded the case for further inquiry to be made in the

arguments.court_reasoning: Notice served within 4 years on March 6, 1951; no time limit for completion of proceedings; AAC remand did not set aside notice.

arguments.claim: Provisions of s.34 Mysore Income-tax Act similar to Rule 34 Mysore Sales Tax Act; proceedings barred per rule in K.S. Subbarayappa case.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the High Court the provisions of s. 34 of the Mysore Income-tax Act were more or less similar to Rule 34 of the Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1948. Hence the present case clearly companyes within the rule laid down by this Court in M s K. S. Subbarayappa and Sons v. State of Mysore  1952  Mysore L. J. 2341 which means that the present proceedings are barred.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: fact served on the respon- dents on March 6, 1951 under s. 34 of the Mysore Act. That numberice was served within four years of the end of the year of

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court erred; s.34 allows completion after 4 years if notice timely; analogy to sales tax rule inapplicable.

arguments.claim: Proceeding for assessment year 1949-50 governed by Mysore Income-tax Act even after merger with Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: Even after the merger of the State of Mysore with the Union of India a proceeding for assessment of income-tax relating to the assessment year 1949-50 has to be heard and disposed of under the Mysore Act.

arguments.claim: Re-assessment under s.34 commences if notice served within 4 years of end of assessment year; may be completed thereafter as no completion time limit prescribed.

anchor.surface_text: A proceeding for re-assessment under s. 34 of the Mysore Act may be commenced if two conditions exist that the profits and gains chargeable to income-tax have escaped assessment or have been assessed at too low a rate, and ii the notice is served within four years of the end of the year of assessment. But if a proper notice is served within the period provided by the section, the proceeding may be completed even after the expiry of four years from the close of the assessment year, for the Act prescribes no period for completion of the proceeding.

arguments.claim: Notice under s.34 served on March 6, 1951 within four years of end of 1949-50 assessment year.

anchor.surface_text: A notice for re-assessment was in fact served on the respondents on March 6, 1951 under s. 34 of the Mysore Act. That notice was served within four years of the end of the year of assessment 1949-50,

arguments.claim: Appellate Assistant Commissioner vacated assessment order of May 21, 1954 but did not set aside s.34 notice; merely remanded for further inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner vacated the order of assessment dated May 21, 1954, but he did not set aside the notice served upon the respondents. He merely remanded the case for further inquiry to be made in the light of the directions given by him.

arguments.claim: High Court erred in holding re-assessment proceeding barred.

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to appreciate the grounds on which it could be held that the proceeding for re-assessment to tax the income which had escaped assessment in the year 1949-50 commenced after due notice served on March 1951 was barred. The High Court was, in our judgment, plainly in error in holding that the proceeding for re- assessment was barred.

arguments.claim: First reference question not pressed before High Court; deemed answered against respondents; cannot be reagitated in writ petition under Art.226.

anchor.surface_text: It must also be remembered that the respondents had under an order of the Commissioner obtained a reference on the first question set out hereinbefore. That question was not pressed before the High Court, and it must be deemed to have been answered against the respondents. That question could not thereafter be reagitated by the respondents in a petition for the issue of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: Even after the merger of the State of Mysore with the Union of India a proceeding for assessment of income-tax relating to the assessment year 1949-50 has to be heard and disposed of under the Mysore Act.

anchor.surface_text: Even after the merger of the State of Mysore with the Union of India a proceeding for assessment of income-tax relating to the assessment year 1949-50 has to be heard and disposed of under the Mysore Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-merger, pre-existing assessment proceedings continue under the state law applicable at initiation.

holdings.text: A proceeding for re-assessment under s. 34 of the Mysore Act may be commenced if two conditions exist that the profits and gains chargeable to income-tax have escaped assessment or have been assessed at too low a rate, and ii the notice is served within four years of the end of the year of assessment. But if a proper notice is served within the period provided by the section, the proceeding may be completed even after the expiry of four years from the close of the assessment year, for the Act prescribes no period for completion of the proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: A proceeding for re-assessment under s. 34 of the Mysore Act may be commenced if two conditions exist that the profits and gains chargeable to income-tax have escaped assessment or have been assessed at too low a rate, and ii the notice is served within four years of the end of the year of assessment. But if a proper notice is served within the period provided by the section, the proceeding may be completed even after the expiry of four years from the close of the assessment year, for the Act prescribes no period for completion of the proceeding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.34 specifies conditions for starting reassessment via notice within four years but imposes no deadline for finishing it.

holdings.text: It is true that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner vacated the order of assessment dated May 21, 1954, but he did not set aside the notice served upon the respondents. He merely remanded the case for further inquiry to be made in the light of the directions given by him.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner vacated the order of assessment dated May 21, 1954, but he did not set aside the notice served upon the respondents. He merely remanded the case for further inquiry to be made in the light of the directions given by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of AAC order shows it annulled only the assessment order, not the initiating notice, preserving the proceeding for fresh inquiry.

holdings.text: It is difficult to appreciate the grounds on which it could be held that the proceeding for re-assessment to tax the income which had escaped assessment in the year 1949-50 commenced after due notice served on March 1951 was barred. The High Court was, in our judgment, plainly in error in holding that the proceeding for re- assessment was barred.

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to appreciate the grounds on which it could be held that the proceeding for re-assessment to tax the income which had escaped assessment in the year 1949-50 commenced after due notice served on March 1951 was barred. The High Court was, in our judgment, plainly in error in holding that the proceeding for re- assessment was barred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Timely notice under s.34 plus AAC remand without annulling notice means no bar by limitation; rejects High Court analogy to sales tax rule.

holdings.text: It must also be remembered that the respondents had under an order of the Commissioner obtained a reference on the first question set out hereinbefore. That question was not pressed before the High Court, and it must be deemed to have been answered against the respondents. That question could not thereafter be reagitated by the respondents in a petition for the issue of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It must also be remembered that the respondents had under an order of the Commissioner obtained a reference on the first question set out hereinbefore. That question was not pressed before the High Court, and it must be deemed to have been answered against the respondents. That question could not thereafter be reagitated by the respondents in a petition for the issue of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failure to press question in prior reference deems it decided adversely; bars re-agitation via constitutional writ.
